I'm taking the advice of JPSartre12 & starting a thread to discuss some of the questions I had after reading that other thread entitled "What caused the Civil War?"
 
 Is it possible to learn from history?
 Is it possible to learn from one's mistakes?
 
 "The people who don't learn from history are doomed to repeat it." A very large problem is created when there is confusion about what actually occurred during a historical timeframe. However, even when the "historical facts" agree, there is still debate & disagreement on how to interpret the information. The ensuing disagreements & debates sometimes become an obstacle to learning.
 
 Albert Einstein wrote:
 
The significant problems we face can not be solved at the same level of thinking we were at when we created them. or We can't solve problems by using the same kind of thinking we used when we created them.

 He also said:
 
Insanity: doing the same thing over and over again and expecting different results.

 I believe a different level of thinking is required to move past a historical event & learn from it. One way to do this might be to admit the mistakes in thinking that originally created the problems. Fr'instance, the concept of slavery & (even worse) practice of slavery resulted from faulty thinking & irrational reasoning. Science has demonstrated (through the Human Genome Project & more) there is no longer any logical underlying basis for racial or ist belief systems. The concept & practice of slavery was based on an irrational belief system which has now been disproved. 
 
 Another problem when it comes to learning from history is created when historical analysis & understanding is distorted or corrupted using Presentism.
 

 Presentism is a mode of historical analysis in which present-day ideas and perspectives are anachronistically introduced into depictions or interpretations of the past. Some modern historians seek to avoid presentism in their work because they believe it creates a distorted understanding of their subject matter.
 
 The Oxford English Dictionary gives the first citation for presentism in its historiographic sense from 1916, and the word may have been in use in this meaning as early as the 1870s. Historian David Hackett Fischer identifies presentism as a logical fallacy also known as the "fallacy of nunc pro tunc". He has written that the "classic example" of presentism was the so-called "Whig history", in which certain eighteenth- and nineteenth-century British historians wrote history in a way that used the past to validate their own political beliefs. This interpretation was presentist because it did not depict the past in objective historical context, but instead viewed history only through the lens of contemporary Whig beliefs. In this kind of approach, which emphasizes the relevance of history to the present, things which do not seem relevant receive little attention, resulting in a misleading portrayal of the past. "Whig history" or "whiggishness" are often used as synonyms for presentism, particularly when the historical depiction in question is teleological or triumphalist. (Please note: can't link) 
 
 
 Presentist style historical analysis, or revisionist history, very often results in using the past to validate or justify present belief systems. Attempting to resolve cognitive dissonance through denial & self-justification doesn't help when trying to learn from the past. If the goal or aim is to "learn from history" this way of thinking bogs us down. Is it possible to learn from one's mistakes if one doesn't admit to making any? The problems seem to multiply exponentially when a nation or country continues to do this. 
 
 I thought of some of these things while reading that other thread entitled "What caused the Civil War?" What would be the reason or motivation to censor, whitewash or otherwise diminish the importance of slavery as a major cause or factor in these discussions? Isn't it enough to admit slavery was one of the most important, if not the most important factor? 
 
 Let's face it, back then, racist belief systems were not confined to any one area of the USA. Racist belief systems were a national problem, not a regional one. Most academic scholars today do not make claims based on one region of the country being uniquely racist. It seems more likely the majority of people back then  held racist beliefs. Why do some people today seem to insist it was one region or another that was uniquely racist? I mean the double standard that looks to find historical justifications for one person or one region to be remembered as war criminals & for another person or region to be operating under purely humanist ideals just seems unreasonable to me. I think it also highlights the problems inherent to a presentist type of history that "uses the past to validate present beliefs." 
 
 After listening to people debate the question of "What caused the Civil War?" I have been left with the impression that the more important question to ask is "What would be the reason or motivation to censor, whitewash or otherwise diminish the importance of slavery as a major cause or factor in these discussions?" 
 
 The only answers I seem to be able to come up with are cognitive dissonance, denial & self-justification. & isn't that the same level of thinking that created the problems in the first place?
 
 Is it possible to learn from history?
 Is it possible to learn from one's mistakes?
